titleInfo.title: Analysis and Explanation of the Representation of the 3-D Warm Core Structure in Tropical Cyclones across Various Reanalysis Datasets

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: The warm core structure of a tropical cyclone (TC) has been previously analyzed through aircraft observations, dropsondes, satellite-borne Advanced Microwave Sounding Unit (AMSU) data, and numerical simulations. It has been shown that aircraft that fly through a TC collect data that represent the warm core of a TC well; however, it has been theorized that microwave and satellite data struggle to resolve and represent the warm core structure throughout the entire center of the TC because of the coarseness of the satellite observations. Numerical simulations have been utilized to study the height of the warm core with a maximum around 4-8 km and have found that the height is nearly constant with varying intensities (Stern and Nolan 2012). This study aims to analyze the warm core structure of a TC through reanalysis datasets (ERA5, ERA-Interim, MERRA2), as these datasets are the only ones outside of aircraft and observations, that can provide long duration data of 3-D and 4-D structure. ERA5 has the finest resolution of the three datasets that are analyzed with MERRA2, and ERA-Interim increasingly coarse. The average temperature anomaly with respect to the whole basin from the zonal mean in all basins is about +4-9K in ERA5, +3-6K in ERA-Interim, and +4-8K in MERRA2 with the West Pacific basin having the highest magnitudes of average temperature anomalies. ERA5 typically sees the highest magnitude in terms of maximum average temperature anomaly while ERA-Interim sees the lowest values in all basins, in addition to most of the datasets showing tropical storms being statistically significantly cooler than all other intensities. The height of the warm core, described here as pressure, was subjectively analyzed through the geopotential height anomalies, and was found to be nearly constant with increasing intensity around 350-400 hPa, with the West Pacific having the highest warm core around 300 hPa. These results suggest that the strength of the warm core varies within each basin and within different reanalysis datasets. The resolution of the datasets carries a large role in how well the warm core is represented, however, the strength is comparable to prior works. The height of the warm core in this study showed to be more constant with differing intensities which is different than what was found in previous works where the height of the warm core increased with intensity.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Robert Hart, Professor Directing Thesis; Zhaohua Wu, Committee Member; Mark Bourassa, Committee Member; Guosheng Liu, Committee Member.
